awd_titl_txt: NSF BSF: Transport, Fluctuation, and Nonequilibrium Phase Transition in Atomically Thin Crystalline Van der Waals Superconductors
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description: 
Superconductivity is a phenomenon where a conductor loses its resistivity entirely at low temperature, and current can flow without energy dissipation. Understanding superconductivity has been one of the most challenging physics problems for past several decades both for fundamental and applicational point of view. In this work, superconductivity in extremely thin materials will be explored by creating atomically thin superconductors with suppressed disorders. To tackle this challenging problem, scientists from Harvard University, Argonne National Laboratory, and Bar Ilan University in Israel will perform the experimental and theoretical study with complementary expertise. This research effort focuses on fundamental understanding of atomically thin crystalline superconducting materials and their structures, seeking discoveries of novel physical phenomena and exploring new quantum device concepts. Work on education and outreach projects is planned, supporting undergraduates and public school teachers. Through these research and educational projects, graduate students and undergraduates are educated in a highly interdisciplinary environment. This international team will promote interaction among the researchers by removing barriers between them through the collaboration enabled by research.


Technical Description: The research focus of this project is studying fluctuation and non-equilibrium states of 2-dimensional (2D) superconductivity. Employing controlled van der Waals (vdW) heterostructure fabrication techniques developed recently, gate-tunable mesoscopic devices will be constructed, based on 2D superconducting crystals samples. The gate/temperature/magnetic field dependence of the Hall effect will be investigated to characterize emergent transport phenomena in the Bose metallic phase. Transport across the artificial magnetic pining array will be explored, realizing tunable Mott transition and vortex drag measurement to understand the superconducting anisotropy. To understand experimental results, a novel theoretical framework will be developed for understanding dynamic properties and fluctuation dynamics near non-equilibrium phase transitions. A part of this research project will also be carried out in collaboration with the expert in Israel who has complementary expertise. The novel physical phenomena emerging in the 2D vdW superconductors may enable quantum device applications. This project will also allow interdisciplinary training and education for participating postdoctoral research fellows, graduate students, undergraduate students and research interns.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, "Transport, Fluctuation, and Nonequilibrium Phase Transition in Atomically Thin Crystalline Van der Waals Superconductors," we conducted collaborative research aimed at advancing our understanding of two-dimensional superconductors composed of van der Waals (vdW) atomic layers.

Intellectual merits: We fabricated mesoscopic crystalline superconductor samples in the 2D limit and studied the Hall effect from its temperature and magnetic field dependence, which we demonstrated in particular in the Bose metallic phase by establishing a closed loop between experiments and theoretical modeling. This work includes the development of a novel theoretical framework for understanding the non-equilibrium Mott transition, the dynamic properties of the Bose metal, and the fluctuation dynamics near the non-equilibrium phase transition.

We also fabricated Josephson junctions between twisted cuprate crystals to study pairing symmetry. To do this, we developed a new cryogenic van der Waals pick-up method that preserves interfacial crystallinity and freezes the surface interstitial oxygen dopant order in place. The result is a new generation of Josephson junctions between twisted Bi2Sr2CaCu2O8+x (BSCCO) crystals that form spontaneously upon contact, with electronic performance approaching that of single-crystal intrinsic junctions, and whose angular dependence robustly reflects the underlying d-wave superconducting order parameter symmetry.

Having established the novel experimental method to probe the pristine interfacial superconductivity of twisted Josephson junctions, it is also possible to explore emergent phenomena that have not been observed before. In particular, at 45° twist angle, where conventional Cooper pair tunneling is forbidden by symmetry, we observed finite supercurrent up to high temperature. Interestingly, this is accompanied by an unusual Fraunhofer interference oscillation period that coexists with the Fraunhofer oscillation periodicity of intrinsic Josephson junctions close to 45°. In addition, fractional Shapiro steps quantized to half-integers appear at exactly 45° twist angle up to the superconducting transition temperature. This is a clear signature of a dominant and unconventional second harmonic current-phase relationship arising from the co-tunnelling of Cooper pairs, which has recently been predicted to support a topological superconducting state that persists above the boiling point of liquid nitrogen, limited only by the superconducting critical temperature of the cuprates.

Broader Impact: As a long-term impact on a major challenge such as effective quantum information processing in emerging technologies, this project pushed the research frontier to realize the next generation of quantum electronic devices based on high-temperature superconductors. The PI and Co-PI closely integrate the education and outreach program with the research at the frontier of low-dimensional superconducting materials. Despite the pandemic situation we faced during this funding period, the PI/co-PI have been training graduate and undergraduate students in quantum matter research at the interface of experimental and theoretical science. This effort benefits the students in their career development in academia and industry, as well as the international collaboration with the BSF partner.
